categories.name: JavaScript
categories.description: Core JavaScript concepts and modern ES6+ features.

categories.name: CSS
categories.description: Modern CSS layout, styling, and design patterns.

questions.title: Hoisting Output
questions.explanation: var variables are hoisted with undefined. let variables are hoisted but reside in the Temporal Dead Zone until their declaration is reached.

questions.title: Loop Scoping
questions.explanation: var is function-scoped; all callbacks share the final value (3). let is block-scoped; each iteration has its own independent value.

questions.title: Arrow Functions & This
questions.explanation: Arrow functions do not have their own 'this'. They inherit it from the surrounding scope (usually window or undefined in modules).

questions.title: Type Coercion
questions.content:
What is the result of `sum(1, '2')`?

```javascript
function sum(a, b) { return a + b; }
```
questions.explanation: JavaScript coerces the number into a string and concatenates them.

questions.title: Variable Typo
questions.explanation: Without 'use strict', assigning to an undeclared variable creates it as a property on the global object.

questions.title: Method Availability
questions.explanation: The method was added to the constructor object itself, not the prototype. To be available to instances, it must be added to Person.prototype.

questions.title: Constructor Without New
questions.explanation: Without 'new', 'this' refers to the global object. sarah is undefined because the function returns nothing.

questions.title: Postfix vs Prefix
questions.explanation: postfix++ returns the value then increments. ++prefix increments then returns the value.

questions.title: Object References
questions.explanation: In JavaScript, objects interact by reference. Changing 'c' also changes 'd' since they point to the same object.

questions.title: Static Methods
questions.explanation: Static methods live only on the class constructor, not on instances.

questions.title: CSS Specificity Order
questions.content: What is the correct order of specificity from highest to lowest?
questions.explanation: Specificity hierarchy: Inline > IDs > Classes/Pseudo-classes > Elements/Pseudo-elements.

questions.title: Box Model Sizing
questions.content: What is the difference between `content-box` and `border-box`?

options.text: border-box includes padding/border in the width
content-box includes padding/border in the width
They are identical in modern browsers

questions.explanation: border-box makes width calculations much easier by including padding and border within the specified width.

questions.title: Flexbox Alignment
questions.content: Which property aligns items along the cross-axis in Flexbox?
questions.explanation: justify-content is for the main axis; align-items is for the cross axis.

questions.title: The !important Flag
questions.content: What is the best practice for using `!important`?

options.text: Use it whenever specificity is hard to manage
Use it only for utility classes or critical overrides

questions.explanation: !important should be used sparingly as it breaks the natural cascade and makes CSS hard to maintain.

questions.title: Position: Absolute
questions.content: An element with `position: absolute` is positioned relative to:
questions.explanation: Absolute positioning looks up the DOM tree for the nearest ancestor with a position other than 'static'.

questions.title: Inherited Properties
questions.content: Which of these properties is inherited by default?
questions.explanation: Text-related properties like font-family, color, and line-height are inherited. Layout properties like margin/padding are not.

questions.title: em vs rem
questions.content: What is the main difference between `em` and `rem` units?

options.text: em is relative to parent; rem is relative to root
em is relative to root; rem is relative to parent

questions.explanation: rem (root em) always scales relative to the HTML element, while em scales relative to the parent's font size.

questions.title: Hiding Elements
questions.content: What is the layout difference between `display: none` and `visibility: hidden`?

options.text: display: none removes space; visibility: hidden keeps space
visibility: hidden removes space; display: none keeps space

questions.explanation: display: none removes the element from the document flow as if it wasn't there. visibility: hidden just hides it visually.

questions.title: CSS Grid Fractional Units
questions.content: What does the `1fr` unit represent in CSS Grid?

options.text: 1 fraction of the available free space

questions.explanation: The 'fr' unit distributes available free space proportionally within the grid container.

questions.title: Individual Flex Alignment
questions.content: Which property overrides `align-items` for a single flex item?
questions.explanation: align-self allows you to override the default alignment for specific items in a flex container.
